overview.short: Rhizobium etli is a Gram-negative, aerobic, motile rod primarily known as a plant-associated nitrogen-fixing bacterium.
overview.clinical_context: Clinical isolation is uncommon; when recovered, it may represent an environmental isolate, contaminant, or rare opportunistic pathogen depending on specimen context.

species_markers.notes: Supports placement among aerobic oxidase-positive rods rather than Enterobacterales.
Aerobic growth supports Rhizobium over many facultative fermenters.
Non-fermenter profile (when tested) fits environmental aerobic rods; sugar panels may be incompletely reported in routine workflows.

common_confusions.reason: Closely related plant-associated Rhizobium with overlapping biochemical profiles.
Closely related taxa; reliable separation often needs MALDI-TOF or sequencing.
Environmental, oxidase-positive aerobic rods can overlap in routine phenotypic patterns.

when_to_question_identification: Oxidase negativity suggests an alternative genus (e.g., Enterobacterales).
Strong lactose fermentation on MacConkey Agar argues against Rhizobium.
Non-motile isolate argues against typical Rhizobium phenotype.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Best practical option for species-level identification among uncommon aerobic Gram-negative rods.
Recommended when precise taxonomic identification is required or MALDI-TOF is inconclusive.
